conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the distance traveled by the car over the 60 seconds based on the given acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows the acceleration \(a\) as a function of time \(t\).
From \(t = 0\) to \(t = 20\) seconds, the acceleration is \(2 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
From \(t = 20\) to \(t = 40\) seconds, the acceleration is \(0 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
From \(t = 40\) to \(t = 60\) seconds, the acceleration is \(-1 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
We will calculate the velocity and position for each segment and then sum them up to find the total distance traveled.

premise: The acceleration from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 20\) seconds is \(2 \, \text{m/s}^2\).
The acceleration from \(t = 20\) to \(t = 40\) seconds is \(0 \, \text{m/s}^2\) and the velocity at \(t = 20\) seconds is \(40 \, \text{m/s}\).
The acceleration from \(t = 40\) to \(t = 60\) seconds is \(-1 \, \text{m/s}^2\) and the velocity at \(t = 40\) seconds is \(40 \, \text{m/s}\).
The velocity from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 20\) seconds is \(v(t) = 2t\).
conclusion: The distance traveled in the first segment is \(400 \, \text{m}\).

premise: The velocity from \(t = 20\) to \(t = 40\) seconds is constant at \(40 \, \text{m/s}\).
conclusion: The distance traveled in the second segment is \(800 \, \text{m}\).

premise: The velocity from \(t = 40\) to \(t = 60\) seconds is \(v(t) = 80 - t\).
conclusion: The distance traveled in the third segment is incomplete.
